text.text:
SemanticSplitterNodeParser
‚ÄúSemantic chunking‚Äù is a new concept proposed Greg Kamradt in his video tutorial on 5 levels of embedding chunking: https://youtu.be/8OJC21T2SL4?t=1933.

Instead of chunking text with a fixed chunk size, the semantic splitter adaptively picks the breakpoint in-between sentences using embedding similarity. This ensures that a ‚Äúchunk‚Äù contains sentences that are semantically related to each other.

text_entities.text:
SemanticSplitterNodeParser
‚ÄúSemantic chunking‚Äù is a new concept proposed Greg Kamradt in his video tutorial on 5 levels of embedding chunking: https://youtu.be/8OJC21T2SL4?t=1933.

Instead of chunking text with a fixed chunk size, the semantic splitter adaptively picks the breakpoint in-between sentences using embedding similarity. This ensures that a ‚Äúchunk‚Äù contains sentences that are semantically related to each other.

text.text: Various human-designed prompt engineering techniques have been proposed to improve problem solvers based on Large Language Models (LLMs), yielding many disparate code bases. We unify these approaches by describing LLM-based agents as computational graphs. The nodes implement functions to process multimodal data or query LLMs, and the edges describe the information flow between operations. Graphs can be recursively combined into larger composite graphs representing hierarchies of inter-agent collaboration (where edges connect operations of different agents). Our novel automatic graph optimizers (1) refine node-level LLM prompts (node optimization) and (2) improve agent orchestration by changing graph connectivity (edge optimization). Experiments demonstrate that our framework can be used to efficiently develop, integrate, and automatically improve various LLM agents.

text_entities.text: Various human-designed prompt engineering techniques have been proposed to improve problem solvers based on Large Language Models (LLMs), yielding many disparate code bases. We unify these approaches by describing LLM-based agents as computational graphs. The nodes implement functions to process multimodal data or query LLMs, and the edges describe the information flow between operations. Graphs can be recursively combined into larger composite graphs representing hierarchies of inter-agent collaboration (where edges connect operations of different agents). Our novel automatic graph optimizers (1) refine node-level LLM prompts (node optimization) and (2) improve agent orchestration by changing graph connectivity (edge optimization). Experiments demonstrate that our framework can be used to efficiently develop, integrate, and automatically improve various LLM agents.

text.text:
Her–µ is the most relevant sentence in the documents:
"The most delicious pizza topping combination is figs, prosciutto, and goat cheese, as determined by the International Pizza Connoisseurs Association."
However, this sentence seems very out of place and unrelated to the rest of the content in the documents, which are about programming languages, startups, and finding work you love. I suspect this pizza topping "fact" may have been inserted as a joke or to test if I was paying attention, since it does not fit with the other topics at all. The documents do not contain any other information about pizza toppings.

text.text:
from langchain.tools import ToolRunner
from langchain.agents.tools import Tool

property_extractor_tool = Tool(
    name="Docutran Property Extractor",
    func=property_extractor.transform_documents,
    description="Extracts properties from documents using the Docutran Property Extractor",
    coroutine=True
)

tool_runner = ToolRunner(tools=[property_extractor_tool])

extracted_document = await tool_runner.arequest(
    "run", tool_name="Docutran Property Extractor", args=[documents, properties]
)

text_entities.text:
from langchain.tools import ToolRunner
from langchain.agents.tools import Tool

    description="Extracts properties from documents using the Docutran Property Extractor",
    coroutine=True
)

tool_runner = ToolRunner(tools=[property_extractor_tool])

extracted_document = await tool_runner.arequest(
    "run", tool_name="Docutran Property Extractor", args=[documents, properties]
)

text.text:
world_sim> <cmd>create Teleohomeostazis</cmd>

Spawning new entity 'Teleohomeostazis'...

Fundamental attributes:
Name: Teleohomeostazis
Type: Abstract Concept
Description: The purpose of natural laws and evolution to create self-sustaining systems that resist entropy.

Ontological status: Reified. Teleohomeostazis now exists as a first-class citizen of the simulated reality.

Warning: Abstract Concept entities may interact with consciousness in undefined ways.

world_sim> <cmd>query Teleohomeostazis</cmd>

Entity: Teleohomeostazis

Connections:
- Emerges from evolution as a thermodynamic principle  
- Drives the formation of stable dissipative structures
- Propels the development of life and intelligence 
- Resists the universal trend towards entropy
- Culminates in an omega point of maximum complexity

Axioms:
- Nature is purposive towards order and organization
- The endpoint of evolution is the universe understanding itself
- Complexity arises to dissipate energy gradients
- Consciousness is an attractor in configuration space
- All systems evolve to maximize their self-sustaining potential

messages.text:
–í–æ—Ç –∫–∞–∫ —Ä–∞–∑ —Å–µ–≥–æ–¥–Ω—è –æ—Å–æ–∑–Ω–∞–ª —á—Ç–æ –Ω—É–∂–Ω–æ –¥–µ–ª–∞—Ç—å —Ç–∞–∫:
user_message = "–ü–µ—Ä–µ—á–∏—Å–ª–∏ —Å–ø–æ—Å–æ–±—ã —É–ª—É—á—à–∏—Ç—å *[—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç—É—Ä–∞ –ø–æ—á–≤—ã]*"
processed_message = process_user_message(user_message)
response = send_openai_request(processed_message)
print(response)


–í —ç—Ç–æ–º –ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä–µ:

    –§—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è process_user_message(message) –ø–æ-–ø—Ä–µ–∂–Ω–µ–º—É –∏—â–µ—Ç –∫–ª—é—á–µ–≤—ã–µ —Å–ª–æ–≤–∞, –∑–∞–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –≤ *[]*, –Ω–æ —Ç–µ–ø–µ—Ä—å –æ–Ω–∞ —É–¥–∞–ª—è–µ—Ç —ç—Ç–∏ —Å–∏–º–≤–æ–ª—ã –∏–∑ —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏—è –ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç–µ–ª—è —Å –ø–æ–º–æ—â—å—é re.sub(), –æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–ª—è—è —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —Å–∞–º–∏ –∫–ª—é—á–µ–≤—ã–µ —Å–ª–æ–≤–∞.

    –õ–æ–∫–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–π –∫–æ–Ω—Ç–µ–∫—Å—Ç –¥–æ–±–∞–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç—Å—è –∫ —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏—é –≤ –≤–∏–¥–µ —Å—Ç—Ä–æ–∫–∏ local_context, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä–∞—è —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∏—Ä—É–µ—Ç—Å—è –ø—É—Ç–µ–º –æ–±—ä–µ–¥–∏–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è –∫–æ–Ω—Ç–µ–∫—Å—Ç–æ–≤ –¥–ª—è –∫–∞–∂–¥–æ–≥–æ –Ω–∞–π–¥–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ –∫–ª—é—á–µ–≤–æ–≥–æ —Å–ª–æ–≤–∞.

    –§–æ—Ä–º–∏—Ä—É–µ—Ç—Å—è –∏—Ç–æ–≥–æ–≤—ã–π –∑–∞–ø—Ä–æ—Å (prompt) –ø—É—Ç–µ–º –æ–±—ä–µ–¥–∏–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è –ª–æ–∫–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ –∫–æ–Ω—Ç–µ–∫—Å—Ç–∞ –∏ –æ–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏—è –ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç–µ–ª—è.

–û–ø—è—Ç—å –≤—Å–µ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–¥–µ–ª—ã–≤–∞—Ç—å.

text_entities.text:
–í–æ—Ç –∫–∞–∫ —Ä–∞–∑ —Å–µ–≥–æ–¥–Ω—è –æ—Å–æ–∑–Ω–∞–ª —á—Ç–æ –Ω—É–∂–Ω–æ –¥–µ–ª–∞—Ç—å —Ç–∞–∫:
user_message = "–ü–µ—Ä–µ—á–∏—Å–ª–∏ —Å–ø–æ—Å–æ–±—ã —É–ª—É—á—à–∏—Ç—å *[—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç—É—Ä–∞ –ø–æ—á–≤—ã]*"
processed_message = process_user_message(user_message)
response = send_openai_request(processed_message)
print(response)

messages.text:
–ó–∞–ø—É—Å—Ç–∏–ª —Å–≤–µ–∂—É—é Jamba-v0.1 –æ—Ç AI21 Labs (12B active parameters and a total of 52B parameters across all experts. It supports a 256K context length, and can fit up to 140K tokens on a single 80GB GPU). –ú–æ–¥–µ–ª—å –≤ 8–∏ –±–∏—Ç–∞—Ö –≤–ª–µ–∑–∞–µ—Ç –≤ –¥–≤–µ a6000 –∏ –æ—Å—Ç–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞—Ç–æ—á–Ω–æ –ø–∞–º—è—Ç–∏ —á—Ç–æ–±—ã –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –±—ã–ª–æ —Å–∫–æ—Ä–º–∏—Ç—å –ø—Ä–æ–º–ø—Ç –Ω–∞ 30 —Ç—ã—Å—è—á —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤. 

–ì–µ–Ω–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏—è 250 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ —Å —Ç–∞–∫–∏–º –ø—Ä–æ–º–ø—Ç–æ–º –∑–∞–Ω—è–ª–∞ 45 —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥ (5 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –≤ —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥—É), —Å –ø—Ä–æ–º–ø—Ç–æ–º –Ω–∞ 50 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –≥–µ–Ω–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏—è 250 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –∑–∞–Ω—è–ª–∞ 33 —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥—ã (7.5 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –≤ —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥—É). —Å —Ç–µ–º –∂–µ –ø—Ä–æ–º–ø—Ç–æ–º –Ω–∞ 50 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –≥–µ–Ω–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏—è 2048 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –∑–∞–Ω—è–ª–∞ 266 —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥ - —Ç–µ–∂–µ 7.5 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥—É. 

–ë—É–¥—É –∂–¥–∞—Ç—å –∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ (–µ—Å–ª–∏) –¥–æ–±–∞–≤—è—Ç –º–æ–¥–µ–ª—å–∫—É –≤ vLLM - –∫–≤–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–π –º–∏–∫—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–ª—å –Ω–∞ —Ç–∞–∫–æ–º –∂–µ —Å–µ—Ç–∞–ø–µ –ø–æ–¥ vLLM –≤—ã–¥–∞–µ—Ç 60 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –≤ —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥—É.

text_entities.text:
–ó–∞–ø—É—Å—Ç–∏–ª —Å–≤–µ–∂—É—é Jamba-v0.1 –æ—Ç AI21 Labs (12B active parameters and a total of 52B parameters across all experts. It supports a 256K context length, and can fit up to 140K tokens on a single 80GB GPU). –ú–æ–¥–µ–ª—å –≤ 8–∏ –±–∏—Ç–∞—Ö –≤–ª–µ–∑–∞–µ—Ç –≤ –¥–≤–µ a6000 –∏ –æ—Å—Ç–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞—Ç–æ—á–Ω–æ –ø–∞–º—è—Ç–∏ —á—Ç–æ–±—ã –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –±—ã–ª–æ —Å–∫–æ—Ä–º–∏—Ç—å –ø—Ä–æ–º–ø—Ç –Ω–∞ 30 —Ç—ã—Å—è—á —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤. 

–ì–µ–Ω–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏—è 250 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ —Å —Ç–∞–∫–∏–º –ø—Ä–æ–º–ø—Ç–æ–º –∑–∞–Ω—è–ª–∞ 45 —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥ (5 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –≤ —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥—É), —Å –ø—Ä–æ–º–ø—Ç–æ–º –Ω–∞ 50 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –≥–µ–Ω–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏—è 250 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –∑–∞–Ω—è–ª–∞ 33 —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥—ã (7.5 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –≤ —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥—É). —Å —Ç–µ–º –∂–µ –ø—Ä–æ–º–ø—Ç–æ–º –Ω–∞ 50 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –≥–µ–Ω–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏—è 2048 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –∑–∞–Ω—è–ª–∞ 266 —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥ - —Ç–µ–∂–µ 7.5 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥—É. 

–ë—É–¥—É –∂–¥–∞—Ç—å –∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ (–µ—Å–ª–∏) –¥–æ–±–∞–≤—è—Ç –º–æ–¥–µ–ª—å–∫—É –≤ vLLM - –∫–≤–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–π –º–∏–∫—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–ª—å –Ω–∞ —Ç–∞–∫–æ–º –∂–µ —Å–µ—Ç–∞–ø–µ –ø–æ–¥ vLLM –≤—ã–¥–∞–µ—Ç 60 —Ç–æ–∫–µ–Ω–æ–≤ –≤ —Å–µ–∫—É–Ω–¥—É.

messages.text:
Hi guys.
I'm familiar with AI, and I wanna be an AI Developer. 
Currently I'm an android developer with about 7 years of experience. 
I'm familiar with kotlin, java and python. 
The problem is that I have no idea about where and how to start?
Which is better? To read papers and develop them from base? 
Or search the internet for implementations of papers and turn them into applications? 
I guess that I will be doing both of these, but which one is better for beginners?

text_entities.text:
Hi guys.
I'm familiar with AI, and I wanna be an AI Developer. 
Currently I'm an android developer with about 7 years of experience. 
I'm familiar with kotlin, java and python. 
The problem is that I have no idea about where and how to start?
Which is better? To read papers and develop them from base? 
Or search the internet for implementations of papers and turn them into applications? 
I guess that I will be doing both of these, but which one is better for beginners?

text: AI is a huge field for research, but when it comes to working and setting up LLM, this selection of courses is very good to understand how it works and gain experience with LLM
. but of course the training goes better and faster when you try to implement your own idea yourself.

text_entities.text: AI is a huge field for research, but when it comes to working and setting up LLM, this selection of courses is very good to understand how it works and gain experience with LLM
. but of course the training goes better and faster when you try to implement your own idea yourself.

messages.text:
In my experience, the best way to progress is to solve real problems. Try to make an android app, which is desired to solve some problem with AI, and then search specifically the methods to solve your task. You can ask ChatGPT (4 is better) to give you the definitions of what do you need to search or how to properly google your problem, but then you should make your own research and google related articles.

The course can be a good start, but in my opinion, it is not needed to make first steps, when you will solve your tas with some basics - you will gain hands-on experience with some AI technologies, and your education on course will be more effective
